definitions.definition: willing to understand and respect other people’s behaviour, opinions, etc., especially when they are different from your own; believing people should be able to choose how they behave

examples.text: liberal attitudes/views/opinions
My parents were very liberal when we were growing up.
He is relatively liberal on social issues.
Her attitudes are fairly liberal.
His later films reflect the more liberal values of the 1960s.
Her parents are very liberal and allow her a lot of freedom.
In some countries there is a more liberal attitude to euthanasia.

definitions.definition: following or supporting political policies that encourage social change and support the sharing of wealth more equally

examples.text: Even in famously liberal New York her views were considered too radical.
Liberal and conservative pundits alike predicted disaster for the campaign.
The media was accused by right-wing commentators of a liberal bias.
He accused them of espousing liberal ideas from the left of the party.

definitions.definition: having or relating to political and social beliefs that support individual freedom and rights, democracy and free enterprise (= businesses competing against each other with little government control)

examples.text: Some politicians want more liberal trade relations with Europe.
liberal democracy
liberal theories
a liberal politician
a challenge to the post-Cold-War liberal consensus
a broadly liberal policy programme
a broadly liberal set of policies
comparatively liberal in trade matters

definitions.definition: connected with the British Liberal Party in the past, or a Liberal Party in another country

examples.text: She is very liberal with her money.
I think Sam is too liberal with his criticism *(= he criticizes people too much)*.
International investors should be allowed more liberal access to our markets to invest in them.
We ate cake with liberal amounts of whipped cream.
She's very liberal with her advice!

definitions.definition: a liberal education is about increasing somebody’s general knowledge and experience rather than particular skills

examples.text: a liberal education
a liberal translation of the text
a **liberal interpretation** of the law

wordOrigin: Middle English: via Old French from Latin liberalis, from liber ‘free (man)’. The original sense was ‘suitable for a free man’, hence ‘suitable for a gentleman’ (one not tied to a trade), surviving in liberal arts. Another early sense ‘generous’ (compare with sense (4)) gave rise to an obsolete meaning ‘free from restraint’, leading to sense (1) (late 18th cent.).
